title: Authors and Citation
text: Hiroyuki Muto. Author, maintainer.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Muto H (2025). mutolabr: Convenient R Functions Frequently Used mutolab. R package version 1.6.0, https://github.com/mutopsy/mutolabr.
code: @Manual{,   title = {mutolabr: Convenient R Functions Frequently Used in mutolab},   author = {Hiroyuki Muto},   year = {2025},   note = {R package version 1.6.0},   url = {https://github.com/mutopsy/mutolabr}, }

title: Convenient R Functions Frequently Used in mutolab
text: mutolabr R package provides convenient functions frequently used mutolab. package includes functions : Conduct frequentist Bayesian t-tests effect size estimation (t_test_all). Perform correlation tests partial correlation tests using frequentist Bayesian methods variables given dataset (cor_test_all, pcor_test_all). Perform contrast tests using frequentist method (contrast_test). Compute summary statistics single variable, including highest density interval (hdi), mode (mode_stat), population variance (var_desc), population standard deviation (sd_desc). Calculate probability direction (pd) MCMC samples posterior distribution. Retrieve list currently loaded R packages along versions (loaded_packages_version).

title: Convenient R Functions Frequently Used in mutolab
text: can install mutolabr GitHub using devtools:
code: # Install devtools if not already installed if (!requireNamespace("devtools", quietly = TRUE)) install.packages("devtools")  # Install mutolabr devtools::install_github("mutopsy/mutolabr")

title: Convenient R Functions Frequently Used in mutolab
text: package requires: * R (>= 4.1.0) * dplyr * tidyr * BayesFactor * effectsize * withr * ggplot2

title: Convenient R Functions Frequently Used in mutolab
text: installation, can load package using library function.
code: library(mutolabr)

title: Convenient R Functions Frequently Used in mutolab
text: details function, refer function references.

title: Convenient R Functions Frequently Used in mutolab
text: t_test_all: Perform Frequentist Bayesian t-tests Effect Size Estimation [Document] cor_test_all: Perform Correlation Tests Frequentist Bayesian Methods [Document] pcor_test_all: Perform Partial Correlation Tests Frequentist Methods [Document] contrast_test: Perform Contrast Tests Frequentist Method [Document] trend_test: Perform Trend Analysis using Contrast Test Frequentist Method [Document] summary_generalTestBF: Summarize Results generalTestBF (beta version) [Document] Note: function direct copy anovakun, developed Prof. Ryuta Iseki. Redistribution minor modifications permitted original author’s policy, provided modifications clearly stated. anovakun_tidy: wrapper anovakun improved usability formatting. [Document] anova_bf: Perform Bayesian ANOVA Using generalTestBF. [Document]

title: Convenient R Functions Frequently Used in mutolab
text: summary_stat: Compute Summary Statistics [Document] var_desc: Compute Population Variance [Document] sd_desc: Compute Population Standard Deviation [Document] mode_stat: Compute Mode Distribution [Document] hdi: Compute Highest Density Interval (HDI) [Document] pdir: Probability Direction (pd) Calculation [Document]

what: Perform ANOVA using the anovakun procedure (version 4.8.9) — anovakun
title: Perform ANOVA using the anovakun procedure (version 4.8.9) — anovakun
text: function performs analysis variance (ANOVA) based anovakun version 4.8.9, originally developed Prof. Ryuta Iseki (Taisho University, Japan).

title: Perform ANOVA using the anovakun procedure (version 4.8.9) — anovakun
code: anovakun(   dataset,   design,   ...,   long = FALSE,   type2 = FALSE,   nopost = FALSE,   tech = FALSE,   data.frame = FALSE,   copy = FALSE,   holm = FALSE,   hc = FALSE,   s2r = FALSE,   s2d = FALSE,   fs1 = FALSE,   fs2r = FALSE,   fs2d = FALSE,   welch = FALSE,   criteria = FALSE,   lb = FALSE,   gg = FALSE,   hf = FALSE,   cm = FALSE,   auto = FALSE,   mau = FALSE,   har = FALSE,   iga = FALSE,   ciga = FALSE,   eta = FALSE,   peta = FALSE,   geta = NA,   eps = FALSE,   peps = FALSE,   geps = NA,   omega = FALSE,   omegana = FALSE,   pomega = FALSE,   gomega = NA,   gomegana = NA,   prep = FALSE,   nesci = FALSE,   besci = FALSE,   cilmd = FALSE,   cilm = FALSE,   cind = FALSE,   cin = FALSE,   ciml = FALSE,   cipaird = FALSE,   cipair = FALSE,   bgraph = c(NA, NA) )

title: Perform ANOVA using the anovakun procedure (version 4.8.9) — anovakun
text: dataset data frame containing input data. design character string specifying experimental design (e.g., "", "ABs", "sA", "sAB", "AsB", etc.). ... Numbers levels factor. long Logical. Whether data long format. type2 Logical. Whether use Type II sums squares (default FALSE Type III). nopost Logical. TRUE, skips post hoc tests. tech Logical. TRUE, returns raw lists results instead printing. data.frame Logical. TRUE, returns reformatted data frame. copy Logical. TRUE, copies output clipboard. holm, ..., bgraph Additional flags controlling specific analyses (see documentation).

title: Perform ANOVA using the anovakun procedure (version 4.8.9) — anovakun
text: Depending arguments, either printed output list ANOVA results.

title: Perform ANOVA using the anovakun procedure (version 4.8.9) — anovakun
text: implementation, code anovakun version 4.8.9 included -modification computational logic output. However, purpose maintainability modularity, internal helper functions separated different file. Additionally, original Japanese-language comments removed source code maintain stylistic consistency package simplify documentation. Redistribution minor modifications original function permitted terms indicated original author, provided modifications clearly stated. implementation complies policy. methodological details rationale, please refer original documentation anovakun version 4.8.9.

title: Perform ANOVA using the anovakun procedure (version 4.8.9) — anovakun

what: A wrapper for anovakun (version 4.8.9) with improved usability and formatting — anovakun2
title: A wrapper for anovakun (version 4.8.9) with improved usability and formatting — anovakun2
text: function serves wrapper around anovakun (version 4.8.9), streamlining common usage patterns mutolab formatting results easier interpretation.

title: A wrapper for anovakun (version 4.8.9) with improved usability and formatting — anovakun2
code: anovakun2(dataset, design, alpha = 0.05, inc_allvar = FALSE, do_round = TRUE)

title: A wrapper for anovakun (version 4.8.9) with improved usability and formatting — anovakun2
text: dataset data frame containing input data long (tidy) format. design character string specifying experimental design (e.g., "", "ABs", "sA", "sAB", "AsB", etc.). alpha Significance level. Defaults 0.05. inc_allvar Logical. TRUE, columns included output. Defaults FALSE. do_round Logical. TRUE, numeric values output rounded readability. Defaults TRUE. ... Additional arguments passed anovakun. number levels factor automatically calculated dataset design, need specified manually.

title: A wrapper for anovakun (version 4.8.9) with improved usability and formatting — anovakun2
text: data frame containing results ANOVA, including F-statistics, p-values, effect sizes, sphericity indices (applicable).

title: A wrapper for anovakun (version 4.8.9) with improved usability and formatting — anovakun2
text: core computation delegated original anovakun function, wrapper automatically infers number factor levels, simplifies output, adds formatting options rounding. full details original implementation anovakun, refer : https://riseki.cloudfree.jp/?ANOVA%E5%90%9B

title: A wrapper for anovakun (version 4.8.9) with improved usability and formatting — anovakun2
code: data_snakemr %>%   anovakun2("sABC") #> Error: object 'is_error' not found

what: Perform Bayesian ANOVA Using generalTestBF — anova_bf
title: Perform Bayesian ANOVA Using generalTestBF — anova_bf
text: Bayesian ANOVA Wrapper Using BayesFactor::generalTestBF

title: Perform Bayesian ANOVA Using generalTestBF — anova_bf
code: anova_bf(   dataset,   design,   rscaleFixed = "medium",   rscaleRandom = "nuisance",   rscaleCont = "medium",   rscaleEffects = NULL,   method = "auto",   progress = TRUE,   multicore = FALSE,   summarize = TRUE,   inc_ranef = FALSE,   seed = NULL )

title: Perform Bayesian ANOVA Using generalTestBF — anova_bf
text: dataset data frame (long) ANOVA format: first column subject identifier, last column dependent variable, columns factors (/within inferred design). design single string specifying design. must contain exactly one "s" (subjects). Letters left "s" -subject factors; letters right "s" within-subject factors. Examples: "sAB" (two within), "ABsC" (two , one within). rscaleFixed Prior scale fixed effects. Default "medium". rscaleRandom Prior scale random effects. Default "nuisance". rscaleCont Prior scale continuous covariates. Default "medium". rscaleEffects Optional vector prior scales individual effects. method Method computing Bayes factors; see BayesFactor::generalTestBF(). Default "auto". progress Logical; show progress bar? Default TRUE. multicore Logical; use multicore processing? Default FALSE. summarize Logical; TRUE (default), return summarized tibble; FALSE, return raw BayesFactor result. inc_ranef Logical; summarizing, also include random-effect terms table (passed mutolabr::summary_generalTestBF()). seed Optional numeric seed reproduce Monte Carlo results; passed withr::with_seed().

title: Perform Bayesian ANOVA Using generalTestBF — anova_bf
text: summarize = TRUE (default), tibble summarizing Bayes factors exclusion term full model, columns: effect Effect removed full model (fixed , optionally, random). BF Bayes factor null (exclusion) vs. alternative (full). error Estimated numerical error. log10_BF Base-10 logarithm BF. favor Whether data favor null alternative. evidence Evidence category (e.g., "anecdotal", "moderate", ...). summarize = FALSE, returns BayesFactor object produced generalTestBF().

title: Perform Bayesian ANOVA Using generalTestBF — anova_bf
text: Runs Bayesian ANOVA -participants, within-participants, mixed designs via BayesFactor::generalTestBF(..., whichModels = "top"), given compact design string (e.g., "sABC", "ABsC"). One subject column, one dependent variable column, factor columns assumed. Internally function: Validates design ("s" must appear exactly ) checks number factor columns matches count implied design. Renames columns "s" (subject), "fb1","fb2",... (), "fw1","fw2",... (within), "y" (outcome), coerces factors. Drops rows missing values unused factor levels. Builds fixed-effect formula including main effects interactions among fb* fw*. Sets random effects s s:fw combinations within-factor subsets except highest-order within interaction (coincides residual error term classical ANOVA). -factor terms included random effects. Standardizes y mean 0 SD 1 prior analysis. Bayes factors computed whichModels = "top" (full model vs. models one term removed) summarized via mutolabr::summary_generalTestBF().

title: Perform Bayesian ANOVA Using generalTestBF — anova_bf
code: # Example 1: between-participants design (design = "ABs")  anova_bf(data_fict_between, design = "ABs", seed = 610, progress = FALSE) #> # A tibble: 3 × 7 #>   effect       type       BF error log10_BF favor evidence  #>   <chr>        <chr>   <dbl> <dbl>    <dbl> <chr> <chr>     #> 1 group        fixed   6.15  0.015   0.789  alt.  moderate  #> 2 gender       fixed 223     0.018   2.35   alt.  extreme   #> 3 group:gender fixed   0.882 0.02   -0.0545 null  anecdotal  # Example 2: within-participants design (design = "sAB")  anova_bf(data_fict_within, design = "sAB", seed = 610, progress = FALSE) #> # A tibble: 3 × 7 #>   effect         type          BF error log10_BF favor evidence    #>   <chr>          <chr>      <dbl> <dbl>    <dbl> <chr> <chr>       #> 1 condition      fixed       1.13  0.26   0.0536 alt.  anecdotal   #> 2 time           fixed 2760000     0.26   6.44   alt.  extreme     #> 3 condition:time fixed      41.6   0.26   1.62   alt.  very strong  # Example 3: mixed design (between = A, within = C)  anova_bf(data_fict_mixed, design = "AsB", seed = 610, progress = FALSE) #> # A tibble: 3 × 7 #>   effect           type     BF error log10_BF favor evidence  #>   <chr>            <chr> <dbl> <dbl>    <dbl> <chr> <chr>     #> 1 gender           fixed  1.45 0.075    0.160 alt.  anecdotal #> 2 condition        fixed  4.37 0.056    0.641 alt.  moderate  #> 3 gender:condition fixed  2.22 0.071    0.347 alt.  anecdotal

title: Perform Contrast Test — contrast_test
text: function performs contrast test given dataset compare means multiple variables using weighted contrasts. calculates several statistics, including t-value, F-value, p-value, confidence intervals, effect sizes (Cohen's f partial eta squared).

title: Perform Contrast Test — contrast_test
code: contrast_test(   dat,   weight = NULL,   paired = FALSE,   alternative = c("two.sided", "less", "greater"),   conf.level = 0.95,   verbose = TRUE )

title: Perform Contrast Test — contrast_test
text: dat data frame tibble containing data analyzed. column represents variable. unbalanced data, please fill missing values NA. weight numeric vector weights apply variable contrast. sum weights must zero. paired logical indicating whether data paired (TRUE) unpaired (FALSE). Default FALSE. alternative character string specifying type test. Possible values "two.sided" (default), "less", "greater". conf.level numeric value indicating confidence level confidence intervals. Default 0.95. verbose Logical. TRUE, prints additional messages.

title: Perform Contrast Test — contrast_test
text: data frame containing following columns: weights weights applied variable contrast. estimate weighted contrast estimate. lower lower bound confidence interval. upper upper bound confidence interval. t t-value contrast. F F-value contrast. df_error degrees freedom error. SS_contrast sum squares contrast component. SS_error sum squares error. SS_effect sum squares effect. SS_total toal sum squares data. p p-value contrast test. eta2 eta squared effect size. peta2 partial eta squared effect size. cohens_f Cohen's f effect size. n_total total number observations unpaired data. n_total_na number missing values unpaired data. n_pair number non-missing pairs paired data. n_pair_na number missing pairs paired data.

title: Perform Contrast Test — contrast_test
text: function performs contrast analysis given dataset using provided weights. computes statistics t-value, F-value, confidence intervals, effect sizes (Cohen's f partial eta squared). data paired, pair-wise exclusion applied. function supports two-tailed one-tailed tests depending value alternative parameter.

title: Perform Contrast Test — contrast_test

what: Perform Correlation Tests with Frequentist and Bayesian Methods — cor_test_all
title: Perform Correlation Tests with Frequentist and Bayesian Methods — cor_test_all
text: function computes pairwise correlations variables given dataset, supporting frequentist Bayesian approaches. provides multiple correlation estimates, confidence intervals, Bayesian credible intervals, probability direction (pd), Bayes factors.

title: Perform Correlation Tests with Frequentist and Bayesian Methods — cor_test_all
code: cor_test_all(   dat,   cor = TRUE,   cor_EAP = FALSE,   cor_MAP = FALSE,   cor_MED = FALSE,   pd = FALSE,   bf = FALSE,   ci = c("freq", "bayes_central", "bayes_hdi"),   triangle = c("upper", "lower", "full"),   alternative = c("two.sided", "less", "greater"),   method = c("pearson", "kendall", "spearman"),   exact = NULL,   conf.level = 0.95,   continuity = FALSE,   rscale_est = "ultrawide",   rscale_bf = "ultrawide",   iterations = 10000,   map_density_n = 512,   ... )

title: Perform Correlation Tests with Frequentist and Bayesian Methods — cor_test_all
text: dat data frame matrix containing numeric variables correlation analysis. cor Logical. TRUE, computes frequentist correlation coefficients (default: TRUE). cor_EAP Logical. TRUE, computes expected posteriori (EAP) estimate correlation coefficient (default: FALSE). cor_MAP Logical. TRUE, computes maximum posteriori (MAP) estimate correlation coefficient (default: FALSE). cor_MED Logical. TRUE, computes median posterior distribution (MED) correlation coefficient (default: FALSE). pd Logical. TRUE, computes probability direction (pd) based posterior distributions (default: FALSE). bf Logical. TRUE, computes Bayes factors presence correlation versus null hypothesis (default: FALSE). ci Character. Specifies type confidence credible interval: "freq" (frequentist confidence interval), "bayes_central" (Bayesian central credible interval), "bayes_hdi" (highest density interval based posterior distribution) (default: "freq"). triangle Character. Specifies part correlation matrix return: "upper", "lower", "full" (default: "upper"). alternative Character. Specifies alternative hypothesis frequentist test: "two.sided", "less", "greater" (default: "two.sided"). method Character. Specifies correlation method frequentist test: "pearson", "kendall", "spearman" (default: "pearson"). exact Logical NULL. TRUE, computes exact p-values small sample sizes using Spearman Kendall correlations. conf.level Numeric. confidence level frequentist intervals credibility level Bayesian intervals (default: 0.95). continuity Logical. TRUE, applies continuity correction Kendall correlations (default: FALSE). rscale_est Numeric character. Specifies Cauchy prior scale Bayesian estimation posterior distribution. Options: "ultrawide", "wide", "medium", positive real number (default: "ultrawide"). Passed BayesFactor::correlationBF(). rscale_bf Numeric character. Specifies Cauchy prior scale Bayes factor calculation. Options: "ultrawide", "wide", "medium", positive real number (default: "ultrawide"). Passed BayesFactor::correlationBF(). iterations Integer. Number MCMC samples Bayesian estimation (default: 10000). map_density_n Integer. Number bins MAP density estimation (default: 512). ... Additional arguments passed cor.test().

title: Perform Correlation Tests with Frequentist and Bayesian Methods — cor_test_all
text: list containing: data frame computed correlation statistics. table_XX data frame corresponding table named "table_XX", "XX" derived output variables (e.g., "table_cor", "table_p", "table_BF10"). content table depends provided inputs.

title: Perform Correlation Tests with Frequentist and Bayesian Methods — cor_test_all

what: Compute the Highest Density Interval (HDI) — hdi
title: Compute the Highest Density Interval (HDI) — hdi
text: function calculates highest density interval (HDI) given set samples. HDI interval contains specified proportion (default 95%) highest density values distribution.

title: Compute the Highest Density Interval (HDI) — hdi
code: hdi(x, prob = 0.95)

title: Compute the Highest Density Interval (HDI) — hdi
text: x numeric vector data values HDI calculated. prob probability mass HDI calculate. Default 0.95.

title: Compute the Highest Density Interval (HDI) — hdi
text: numeric vector length 2 representing lower upper bounds HDI.

title: Compute the Highest Density Interval (HDI) — hdi
text: function first sorts input data computes necessary quantiles using inear interpolation. identifies interval contains highest density, ensuring HDI encompasses specified probability mass. Note function support case two separate HDIs exist.

title: Compute the Highest Density Interval (HDI) — hdi
code: set.seed(123) data <- rnorm(1000)  # Generate random normal data hdi(data, prob = 0.95) #> [1] -2.053247  1.879089

what: Get a list of currently loaded packages and their versions — loaded_packages_version
title: Get a list of currently loaded packages and their versions — loaded_packages_version
text: function retrieves names versions currently loaded R packages. returns data frame package names first column respective versions second column.

title: Get a list of currently loaded packages and their versions — loaded_packages_version
code: loaded_packages_version()

title: Get a list of currently loaded packages and their versions — loaded_packages_version
text: data frame two columns: package name loaded package. version version loaded package.

title: Get a list of currently loaded packages and their versions — loaded_packages_version
code: # Get the list of loaded packages with versions loaded_packages_version() #>         package    version #> 1   BayesFactor 0.9.12.4.7 #> 2          MASS     7.3.64 #> 3        Matrix      1.7.2 #> 4  MatrixModels      0.5.4 #> 5            R6      2.6.1 #> 6          Rcpp     1.0.14 #> 7          base      4.4.3 #> 8    bayestestR     0.15.2 #> 9         bslib      0.9.0 #> 10       cachem      1.1.0 #> 11          cli      3.6.4 #> 12         coda   0.19.4.1 #> 13   colorspace      2.1.1 #> 14     compiler      4.4.3 #> 15         curl      6.2.2 #> 16     datasets      4.4.3 #> 17   datawizard      1.0.2 #> 18         desc      1.4.3 #> 19     devtools      2.4.5 #> 20       digest     0.6.37 #> 21      downlit      0.4.4 #> 22        dplyr      1.1.4 #> 23   effectsize what: Compute the Mode of a Distribution — mode_stat
title: Compute the Mode of a Distribution — mode_stat
text: function estimates mode (frequent value) given numeric vector using kernel density estimation. mode identified value kernel density maximized.

title: Compute the Mode of a Distribution — mode_stat
code: mode_stat(z, n = 512)

title: Compute the Mode of a Distribution — mode_stat
text: z numeric vector containing values mode estimated. n integer specifying number equally spaced grid points kernel density estimation (default 512).

title: Compute the Mode of a Distribution — mode_stat
text: numeric value representing estimated mode distribution.

title: Compute the Mode of a Distribution — mode_stat
code: # Generate random data from a normal distribution set.seed(123) data <- rnorm(1000)  # Compute the mode of the distribution mode_stat(data) #> [1] 0.006799071

what: Internal Helper Functions for anovakun — mutolabr-package
title: Internal Helper Functions for anovakun — mutolabr-package
text: file contains internal functions used within anovakun package. functions exported used directly end users.

title: Internal Helper Functions for anovakun — mutolabr-package
text: Maintainer: Hiroyuki Muto mutopsy@omu.ac.jp

what: Perform Partial Correlation Tests with Frequentist Methods — pcor_test_all
title: Perform Partial Correlation Tests with Frequentist Methods — pcor_test_all
text: Computes pairwise partial correlations among variables given dataset, controlling one covariates using frequentist methods. function returns correlation estimates along confidence intervals. Note: Bayesian methods supported current version.

title: Perform Partial Correlation Tests with Frequentist Methods — pcor_test_all
code: pcor_test_all(   dat,   control = NULL,   triangle = c("upper", "lower", "full"),   alternative = c("two.sided", "less", "greater"),   method = c("pearson", "kendall", "spearman"),   conf.level = 0.95,   ... )

title: Perform Partial Correlation Tests with Frequentist Methods — pcor_test_all
text: dat data frame matrix containing numeric variables interest. control data frame, matrix, numeric vector containing covariates control . triangle Character. Specifies part correlation matrix return: "upper", "lower", "full" (default: "upper"). alternative Character. Specifies alternative hypothesis frequentist test: "two.sided", "less", "greater" (default: "two.sided"). method Character. Specifies correlation method frequentist test: "pearson", "kendall", "spearman" (default: "pearson"). conf.level Numeric. confidence level confidence intervals (default: 0.95). cor Logical. TRUE, computes frequentist correlation coefficients (default: TRUE).

title: Perform Partial Correlation Tests with Frequentist Methods — pcor_test_all
text: list containing: data frame computed correlation statistics. table_XX data frame corresponding table named "table_XX", "XX" derived output variables (e.g., "table_cor", "table_p"). content table depends provided inputs.

title: Perform Partial Correlation Tests with Frequentist Methods — pcor_test_all
code: results <- pcor_test_all(mtcars[, 1:3], control = mtcars[, 4:5]) results$all  # View detailed results in a tidy format #>   var_row var_col row col        cor      lower        upper         t df #> 1     mpg     cyl   1   2 -0.3302412 -0.6170915  0.034083055 -1.851339 28 #> 2     mpg    disp   1   3 -0.3615918 -0.6386623 -0.001520729 -2.052225 28 #> 3     cyl    disp   2   3  0.5077685  0.1805229  0.733801007  3.118837 28 #>             p n_pair n_na #> 1 0.074695109     32    0 #> 2 0.049602794     32    0 #> 3 0.004177802     32    0 results$table_cor  # View partial correlation matrix #>      mpg        cyl       disp #> mpg   NA -0.3302412 -0.3615918 #> cyl   NA         NA  0.5077685 #> disp  NA         NA         NA

title: Probability of Direction (pd) Calculation — pdir
text: function calculates probability direction (pd), proportion distribution sign median’s varies 0.50 1.00. index effect existence, proposed Makowski et al. (2019).

title: Probability of Direction (pd) Calculation — pdir
code: pdir(x, na.rm = FALSE)

title: Probability of Direction (pd) Calculation — pdir
text: x numeric vector values. na.rm logical value indicating whether NA values removed calculation. Default FALSE.

title: Probability of Direction (pd) Calculation — pdir
text: numeric value 0 1, representing Probability Direction (Pd). value calculated proportion positive values x, 1 minus proportion less 0.5.

title: Probability of Direction (pd) Calculation — pdir
text: Makowski, D., Ben-Shachar, M. S., Chen, S. H. ., & Lüdecke, D. (2019). Indices effect existence significance Bayesian framework. Frontiers Psychology, 10, Article 2767. https://doi.org/10.3389/fpsyg.2019.02767

title: Probability of Direction (pd) Calculation — pdir
code: set.seed(123) x <- rnorm(1000) pdir(x)  # Returns the Probability of Direction for x #> [1] 0.505 pdir(x, na.rm = TRUE)  # Removes NA values before calculation #> [1] 0.505

what: Perform Bayesian Repeated-Measures ANOVA Using generalTestBF — rmANOVA_bf
title: Perform Bayesian Repeated-Measures ANOVA Using generalTestBF — rmANOVA_bf
text: Performs Bayesian repeated-measures ANOVA using generalTestBF(..., whichModels = "top") function BayesFactor package, assuming one subject column, multiple within-subject factor columns, one dependent variable column.

title: Perform Bayesian Repeated-Measures ANOVA Using generalTestBF — rmANOVA_bf
code: rmANOVA_bf(   x,   rscaleFixed = "medium",   rscaleRandom = "nuisance",   rscaleCont = "medium",   rscaleEffects = NULL,   method = "auto",   progress = TRUE,   multicore = FALSE,   summarize = TRUE,   inc_ranef = FALSE,   seed = NULL )

title: Perform Bayesian Repeated-Measures ANOVA Using generalTestBF — rmANOVA_bf
text: x data frame long format. first column subject identifier. last column dependent variable, columns within-subject factors. rscaleFixed Prior scale fixed effects. Default "medium". rscaleRandom Prior scale random effects. Default "nuisance". rscaleCont Prior scale continuous covariates. Default "medium". rscaleEffects Optional vector prior scales individual effects. method Method computing Bayes factors. See BayesFactor::generalTestBF(). Default "auto". progress Logical. Whether display progress bar. Default TRUE. multicore Logical. Whether use multicore processing. Default FALSE. summarize Logical. Whether output summarized results . Default 'TRUE'. inc_ranef Logical. Whether output results random effects. seed Optional. numeric seed fix random number generator state reproducibility.

title: Perform Bayesian Repeated-Measures ANOVA Using generalTestBF — rmANOVA_bf
text: tibble summarizing Bayes factors model compared full model. Columns include: effect effect excluded full model BF Bayes factor null (exclusion) alternative hypothesis error Estimated numerical error log10_BF Base-10 logarithm Bayes factor favor Indicates whether data favor null alternative hypothesis evidence Strength evidence ("anecdotal", "moderate", "strong", "strong", "extreme")

title: Perform Bayesian Repeated-Measures ANOVA Using generalTestBF — rmANOVA_bf
text: function currently supports designs 2 3 within-subject factors . subject column automatically renamed "s", factor columns "fw1", "fw2", etc., outcome variable "y" internally formula construction.

title: Perform Bayesian Repeated-Measures ANOVA Using generalTestBF — rmANOVA_bf
Compute Population Standard Deviation — sd_desc
text: function calculates population standard deviation numeric vector. Unlike default sd() function R, computes sample standard deviation, function adjusts calculation use n instead n-1 denominator.

title: Compute Population Standard Deviation — sd_desc
code: sd_desc(x, na.rm = FALSE)

title: Compute Population Standard Deviation — sd_desc
text: x numeric vector containing data. na.rm logical value indicating whether remove missing values (NA) computation. Default FALSE.

title: Compute Population Standard Deviation — sd_desc
text: numeric value representing population standard deviation x.

title: Compute Population Standard Deviation — sd_desc
code: data <- c(10, 20, 30, 40, 50, NA) sd_desc(data)          # Compute standard deviation including NA (returns NA) #> [1] NA sd_desc(data, na.rm = TRUE)  # Compute standard deviation ignoring NA #> [1] 14.14214

title: Summarize Results from generalTestBF — summary_generalTestBF
text: function summarizes output generalTestBF(..., whichModels = "top") BayesFactor package. computes Bayes factor (BF) favor excluding variable full model, classifies strength evidence based log BF scale.

title: Summarize Results from generalTestBF — summary_generalTestBF
code: summary_generalTestBF(x, inc_ranef = FALSE)

title: Summarize Results from generalTestBF — summary_generalTestBF
text: x object returned generalTestBF(), named list containing: res_BF object returned generalTestBF() variables Character vector variable names full_model_vars Character vector variables full model inc_ranef Logical. Whether output results random effects.

title: Summarize Results from generalTestBF — summary_generalTestBF
text: tibble one row per model comparison. Columns include: effect effect excluded full model type Indicates whether term Fixed random effect BF Bayes factor null (exclusion) alternative hypothesis error Estimated numerical error log10_BF Base-10 logarithm Bayes factor favor Indicates whether data favor null alternative hypothesis evidence Strength evidence ("anecdotal", "moderate", "strong", "strong", "extreme")

title: Summarize Results from generalTestBF — summary_generalTestBF
code: library(BayesFactor) set.seed(123) dat <- data.frame(  id = as.factor(rep(1:30, each = 4)),  A = as.factor(rep(c("low", "high"), times = 60)),  B = as.factor(rep(c("left", "right"), each = 2, times = 30)),  y = rnorm(120) )  res <- generalTestBF(  y ~ A + B + A:B + id + A:id + B:id,  data = dat,  whichRandom = c("id", "A:id", "B:id"),  whichModels = "top" )  summary_generalTestBF(res) #> # A tibble: 6 × 7 #>   effect type      BF error log10_BF favor evidence    #>   <chr>  <chr>  <dbl> <dbl>    <dbl> <chr> <chr>       #> 1 A      fixed 0.239  0.043   -0.622 null  moderate    #> 2 B      fixed 0.248  0.039   -0.605 null  moderate    #> 3 id     fixed 0.0331 0.038   -1.48  null  very strong #> 4 A:B    fixed 0.477  0.022   -0.321 null  anecdotal   #> 5 A:id   fixed 0.473  0.028   -0.325 null  anecdotal   #> 6 B:id   fixed 4.87   0.024    0.687 alt.  moderate

title: Compute Summary Statistics — summary_stat
text: function calculates summary statistics given numeric vector, including mean, standard deviation, quartiles, missing value counts. function supports population sample standard deviation calculations.

title: Compute Summary Statistics — summary_stat
code: summary_stat(x, descriptive = FALSE)

title: Compute Summary Statistics — summary_stat
text: x numeric vector containing sample data. descriptive logical value indicating whether use descriptive (population) standard deviation (TRUE) sample standard deviation (FALSE, default).

title: Compute Summary Statistics — summary_stat
text: data frame following columns: mean mean non-missing values x. sd standard deviation non-missing values x. q25 25th percentile (first quartile). q50 50th percentile (median). q75 75th percentile (third quartile). n_val count non-missing values. n_na count missing values.

title: Compute Summary Statistics — summary_stat
code: # Generate example data set.seed(123) data <- c(rnorm(100, mean = 50, sd = 10), NA, NA)  # Compute summary statistics summary_stat(data) #>       mean       sd      min      q25      q50      q75      max n_val n_na #> 1 50.90406 9.128159 26.90831 45.06146 50.61756 56.91819 71.87333   100    2 summary_stat(data, descriptive = TRUE) #>       mean       sd      min      q25      q50      q75      max n_val n_na #> 1 50.90406 9.082403 26.90831 45.06146 50.61756 56.91819 71.87333   100    2

title: A Default ggplot2 Theme — theme_gg0
text: Returns simplified ggplot2 theme based theme_bw(), grid lines removed, black axis text, legend title. theme useful producing cleaner, publication-ready plots.

title: A Default ggplot2 Theme — theme_gg0
code: theme_gg0(...)

title: A Default ggplot2 Theme — theme_gg0
text: ggplot2 theme object.

title: A Default ggplot2 Theme — theme_gg0
code: library(ggplot2) ggplot(mtcars, aes(x = wt, y = mpg)) +   geom_point() +   theme_gg0()

what: Perform Trend Analysis Using Contrast Test — trend_test
title: Perform Trend Analysis Using Contrast Test — trend_test
text: function conducts trend analysis applying contrast tests given dataset.

title: Perform Trend Analysis Using Contrast Test — trend_test
code: trend_test(   dat,   order = 1:3,   paired = FALSE,   alternative = c("two.sided", "less", "greater"),   conf.level = 0.95,   verbose = TRUE )

title: Perform Trend Analysis Using Contrast Test — trend_test
text: dat data frame matrix containing data. Columns represent different levels independent variable. order integer vector specifying trend orders test. Defaults 1:3. paired Logical. TRUE, paired contrast test performed. Defaults FALSE. alternative character string specifying alternative hypothesis. One "two.sided", "less", "greater". Defaults "two.sided". conf.level Confidence level test. Defaults 0.95. verbose Logical. TRUE, displays messages. Defaults TRUE.

title: Perform Trend Analysis Using Contrast Test — trend_test
text: data frame containing results contrast tests, additional column indicating trend order.

title: Perform Trend Analysis Using Contrast Test — trend_test
text: function constructs contrast vectors specified trend orders using polynomial contrasts (contr.poly). , contrast_test() applied test contrast. details testing procedure, refer documentation contrast_test().

title: Perform Trend Analysis Using Contrast Test — trend_test

what: Perform Frequentist and Bayesian t-tests with Effect Size Estimation — t_test_all
title: Perform Frequentist and Bayesian t-tests with Effect Size Estimation — t_test_all
text: function performs frequentist Bayesian t-tests, options effect size estimation, confidence intervals, Bayesian credible intervals, probability direction (pd), Bayes factors.

title: Perform Frequentist and Bayesian t-tests with Effect Size Estimation — t_test_all
code: t_test_all(   x,   y = NULL,   var.label = c("x", "y"),   paired = F,   var.equal = FALSE,   mu = 0,   ci = c("freq", "bayes_central", "bayes_hdi"),   alternative = c("two.sided", "less", "greater"),   conf.level = 0.95,   pd = FALSE,   bf = FALSE,   cor = TRUE,   mean_x_EAP = FALSE,   mean_x_MAP = FALSE,   mean_x_MED = FALSE,   diff_EAP = FALSE,   diff_MAP = FALSE,   diff_MED = FALSE,   cohens_d = NULL,   cohens_d_EAP = FALSE,   cohens_d_MAP = FALSE,   cohens_d_MED = FALSE,   cohens_dz = TRUE,   cohens_dz_EAP = FALSE,   cohens_dz_MAP = FALSE,   cohens_dz_MED = FALSE,   rscale_est = Inf,   rscale_bf = "medium",   iterations = 10000,   map_density_n = 512,   verbose = TRUE )

title: Perform Frequentist and Bayesian t-tests with Effect Size Estimation — t_test_all
text: x numeric vector representing first sample. y optional numeric vector representing second sample. NULL, one-sample t-test performed (default: NULL). var.label character vector length two specifying labels x y. paired Logical. TRUE, paired t-test performed (default: FALSE). var.equal Logical. TRUE, two-sample t-test assumes equal variances (default: FALSE). mu numeric value specifying null hypothesis mean difference. ci Character. Specifies type confidence credible interval: "freq" (frequentist confidence interval), "bayes_central" (Bayesian central credible interval), "bayes_hdi" (highest density interval based posterior distribution) (default: "freq"). alternative Character. Specifies alternative hypothesis frequentist test: "two.sided", "less", "greater" (default: "two.sided"). conf.level Numeric. confidence level frequentist intervals credibility level Bayesian intervals (default: 0.95). pd Logical. TRUE, computes probability direction (pd) based posterior distributions (default: FALSE). bf Logical. TRUE, computes Bayes factors presence difference versus null hypothesis (default: FALSE). cor Logical. TRUE, computes Pearson correlation paired samples. mean_x_EAP Logical. TRUE, computes expected posteriori (EAP) estimate mean x (default: FALSE). mean_x_MAP Logical. TRUE, computes maximum posteriori (MAP) estimate mean x (default: FALSE). mean_x_MED Logical. TRUE, computes median posterior distribution (MED) mean x (default: FALSE). diff_EAP Logical. TRUE, computes expected posteriori (EAP) estimate mean difference (default: FALSE). diff_MAP Logical. TRUE, computes maximum posteriori (MAP) estimate mean difference (default: FALSE). diff_MED Logical. TRUE, computes median posterior distribution (MED) mean difference (default: FALSE). cohens_d Logical. TRUE, computes Cohen's d independent samples. cohens_d_EAP Logical. TRUE, computes expected posteriori (EAP) estimate Cohen's d (default: FALSE). cohens_d_MAP Logical. TRUE, computes maximum posteriori (MAP) estimate Cohen's d (default: FALSE). cohens_d_MED Logical. TRUE, computes median posterior distribution (MED) Cohen's d (default: FALSE). cohens_dz Logical. TRUE, computes Cohen's dz paired samples. cohens_dz_EAP Logical. TRUE, computes expected posteriori (EAP) estimate Cohen's dz (default: FALSE). cohens_dz_MAP Logical. TRUE, computes maximum posteriori (MAP) estimate Cohen's dz (default: FALSE). cohens_dz_MED Logical. TRUE, computes median posterior distribution (MED) Cohen's dz (default: FALSE). rscale_est Numeric character. Specifies Cauchy prior scale Bayesian estimation posterior distribution. Options: "ultrawide", "wide", "medium", positive real number (default: Inf). Passed BayesFactor::ttestBF(). rscale_bf Numeric character. Specifies Cauchy prior scale Bayes factor calculation. Options: "ultrawide", "wide", "medium", positive real number (default: "medium"). Passed BayesFactor::ttestBF(). iterations Integer. Number MCMC iterations Bayesian estimation. map_density_n Integer. Number bins MAP density estimation. verbose Logical. TRUE, prints additional messages.

title: Perform Frequentist and Bayesian t-tests with Effect Size Estimation — t_test_all
text: data frame containing test statistics, effect sizes, confidence intervals, Bayesian estimates.

title: Perform Frequentist and Bayesian t-tests with Effect Size Estimation — t_test_all
Compute Population Variance — var_desc
text: function calculates population variance numeric vector. Unlike default var() function R, computes sample variance, function adjusts calculation use n instead n-1 denominator.

title: Compute Population Variance — var_desc
code: var_desc(x, na.rm = FALSE)

title: Compute Population Variance — var_desc
text: x numeric vector containing data. na.rm logical value indicating whether remove missing values (NA) computation. Default FALSE.

title: Compute Population Variance — var_desc
text: numeric value representing population variance x.

title: Compute Population Variance — var_desc
code: data <- c(10, 20, 30, 40, 50, NA) var_desc(data)          # Compute variance including NA (returns NA) #> [1] NA var_desc(data, na.rm = TRUE)  # Compute variance ignoring NA #> [1] 200

title: mutolabr 1.6.0 (2025-09-09)
text: Implemented anova_bf().

title: mutolabr 1.5.0 (2025-07-24)
text: Implemented anovakun(), direct copy anovakun version 4.8.9, originally developed Prof. Ryuta Iseki (Taisho University, Japan). Redistribution minor modifications original function permitted terms specified original author, provided modifications clearly stated. implementation includes modifications computational logic complies policy. details, see function documentation; original documentation Prof. Iseki available : https://riseki.cloudfree.jp/?ANOVA%E5%90%9B Implemented anovakun_tidy(), wrapper around anovakun() improves usability. function automatically determines number factor levels dataset, formats output tidy data frame, adds commonly used effect size measures rounding options facilitate reporting interpretation.

title: mutolabr 1.4.0 (2025-06-22)
text: Implemented rmANOVA_bf(), summary_generalTestBF(), theme_gg0().

title: mutolabr 1.3.0 (2025-04-30)
text: Implemented pcor_test_all(). Refined output formatting cor_test_all() using Kendall method.

title: mutolabr 1.2.1 (2025-03-28)
text: Refined output formatting contrast_test().

title: mutolabr 1.2.0 (2025-03-27)
text: Implemented trend_test().

title: mutolabr 1.1.0 (2025-03-26)
text: Implemented contrast_test().

title: mutolabr 1.0.0 (2025-03-26)
text: Initial release mutolabr package. Implemented t_test_all(), cor_test_all(), summary_stat(), var_desc(), sd_desc(), mode_stat(), hdi(), pdir().
